posts.cooked:
Hey everyone!

I’m curious about how I can improve the driving experience for our drive team this year in our code. The swerve worked fine last year, but the robot always seemed sort of jumpy at slow speeds or not super responsive at high speeds. (Some of that may have to do with controller deadbands)

We’re using YAGSL, and here’s our code: GitHub - RoNexRobotics/Swerve8551

It’s probably got something to do with the PID controllers but I wanted to make sure I wasn’t missing something. What I want is extremely fine and smooth movement, such that if the driver is slowly navigating around a small space it isn’t jumpy or quick, but at the same time if he is driving across the field and around robots, it will be quick and responsive enough for that.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked:
SirFire:

(Some of that may have to do with controller deadbands)

What controllers are you currently using? My alum team switched from Logitech F310s (those cheap dark blue wired ones) to the standard Xbox ones this past season (between comps), and there was a noticeable improvement on some funny things the drivetrain had been doing. Better controllers will not fix all your issues, but they might help with some of them.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
in addition to getting genuine controllers (xbox, dualshock, etc.), you could also use a slew rate limiter to decrease the jumpiness

another thing you could try (depending on the next FRC game) is adding a “slow mode”, for example in crescendo we had a slow mode that could be activated by pushing down on a joystick, which was useful for placing game pieces.

finally, you could also add a curve. take a look at this desmos graph and play with n a little. what you could do is directly plug your joystick’s coords into a function like this and use the scaled output to increase precision at low speeds, at the cost of decreasing precision at the high speeds

link_counts.title: Slew Rate Limiter — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
SirFire:

The swerve worked fine last year, but the robot always seemed sort of jumpy at slow speeds or not super responsive at high speeds. (Some of that may have to do with controller deadbands)

Minimize deadbands as much as possible. If the gamepads aren’t drifting, don’t add more deadzones in code as this decreases responsiveness, resulting in sudden jumps when leaving the deadzone without proper compensation, and decreasing drivetrain responsiveness at speed even with compensation. Cheap gamepads with large deadzones, such as the logitech f310s, are almost undriveable because the large deadzones in both cardinal axis prevent precise movement. It is worth the upgrade to get good quality controllers to both move precisely at low speeds, and more importantly, move with appropriate finesse at the robot’s maximum speed.
Last year we used an ineffective method to scale power, we have recently improved it to scale power in a certain direction. Have you tried the newer versions?

Yeah, we’re using the Logitech F310. We also have the standard joystick (I don’t remember the name of it) that our drive team this year seems to want to use instead of the controller. Does the joystick have similar issues?

nevadexehs:

you could also use a slew rate limiter to decrease the jumpiness

Doesn’t YAGSL already have that implemented? I’m seeing a “rampRate” in the physicalProperties.json file of the YAGSL configuration.

I did hear about that, and the code I linked above has this: image 870×146 13.8 KB Is this the newer version that you’re referring to?

image 870×146 13.8 KB

image 870×146 13.8 KB

Looking at the code used for the 2024 competition, it was either multiplying the inputs by 3 or cubing the inputs. I don’t remember which. (Both are present but the cubing method is commented out in our latest commit)

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked: We do what’s already been suggested here, which is raise the input from the joystick to a power(I believe it’s something weird like 2.3 cuz I liked it the best), which essentially makes your inputs with less deflection(fine adjustments and slow speed) less sensitive, so you should get less of those jerky movements. This also lets you raise the max sensitivity higher for more response at big deflections.
Yes it is! Sorry I didn’t link that earlier. Someone pointed out that cubing it and multiplying it doesn’t work with vectors. So we convert to polar, scale, then convert back.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: sounds about right. im not at all familiar with yagsl but looking at our swerve code, we use it and it works for us.

SirFire:

Yeah, we’re using the Logitech F310

There’s your problem. Get a nicer gamepad (official xbox gamepads work, you can spend more for hall effect sticks) and you will see a night and day performance. Software fixes aren’t going to fix a gamepad that just doesn’t work/

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: in addition to control issues, we also had tons of weird times where theyd just take PTO for a few days and not work at all. sometimes no connection, sometimes the mappings would change. no wonder oceangate

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
The WPILib “applyDeadband” function already accounts for this. It rescaled the output to account for the deadband.

So even if you set the deadband to 0.1, your deadbanded output won’t suddenly jump to 0.11 or whatever. That upper 90% of travel is rescaled to 100%.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Here’s a few things we’ve done to aid the driver:

Run PID on the gyro angle of the robot, to help automatically maintain the robot’s orientation on the field. So even if the driver clips a field element, or another robot, the driver doesn’t have to correct the robot’s orientation.

Use a traction control algorithm which automatically tries to limit wheel slip, and makes acceleration more manageable. It also helps in wheel wear.

Create “input maps” for both throttle and rotation input. This allows for fine tuned customisation of the input curve on both sticks to suit the particular preferences of the driver. We do this via PolynomialSplineFunction from the Apache commons math library.

This one wasn’t much use this year for us, since our robot was very small, but we have an automatic anti-tip function. The robot basically monitors the pitch and roll angle, and if it goes beyond some threshold, it will automatically drive in the direction of the tip, in the hopes of catching itself.

Automate as many tasks as possible. Each button shouldn’t just be controlling a motor (in general anyway). Each button should be a complete action, so as to ease the mental load on the driver. Further, if you find that you need two controllers for your robot, you likely haven’t automated enough functionality. This also plays into your design process; design a robot such that the common game actions are easy to automate.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
viggy96:

Run PID on the gyro angle of the robot, to help automatically maintain the robot’s orientation on the field. So even if the driver clips a field element, or another robot, the driver doesn’t have to correct the robot’s orientation.

Genius

The biggest initial impact you are going to see is in controllers. I’ve actually worked in the video game industry for 20 years and I can tell you with authority the logitech (and most off brand knockoffs) controllers are just terrible.

Spend a little money and get Xbox controllers(Xbox elite if you can as the stick extensions are nice) or the excellent PlayStation controllers. I’ve also been told the gamesir controller is good.

Start with the inputs and work from there. There are a lot of things you can do in code to smooth out the experience, but start from the controller and work your way into those changes.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
SirFire:

image 870×146 13.8 KB

image 870×146 13.8 KB

image 870×146 13.8 KB

This code is only cubing the rotation input.  The translations have no characterization other than linear scaling to 80% of max velocity.  I looked around the code and didn’t see another place where the translation inputs were characterized.

I’m not surprised that your robot seems jumpy if you are using the raw translation inputs.  You should consider a Math.pow function on the translation inputs.  Cubing is pretty extreme.  Something more in the vicinity of squaring is likely to work better for translation.

You should also check the stick response on your controllers.  Ideally, your translation stick X and Y outputs will get to 1.0 just as the stick reaches the limit of movement.  I’ve seen sticks that hit 1.0 output after only about 70% of movement toward the stop.  If you aren’t able to make use of the entire range of motion of the stick, your driving is going to be more jumpy.

I also see that your code is using a 0.05 deadband.  Do your sticks consistently hold less than 0.05 output on both axes when released?  A nice hall-effect sensor will do that easily, but that’s going to be a challenge for most potentiometer sensors that have a bit of use on them.  You might need to bump up your deadband to 0.1.

paulonis:

I also see that your code is using a 0.05 deadband. Do your sticks consistently hold less than 0.05 output on both axes when released? A nice hall-effect sensor will do that easily, but that’s going to be a challenge for most potentiometer sensors that have a bit of use on them. You might need to bump up your deadband to 0.1.

That repository is kind of a base swerve template I wrote over the summer for use during swerve demonstrations and things, so we haven’t done extensive testing and fine-tuning with that specific repo. It looks like our deadband for our 2024 comp was 0.06, so not much better but I don’t remember any issues with the robot jumping when nobody was actively driving.

viggy96:

Run PID on the gyro angle of the robot, to help automatically maintain the robot’s orientation on the field. So even if the driver clips a field element, or another robot, the driver doesn’t have to correct the robot’s orientation.

YAGSL has support for this already, any it’s a good feature except that it takes a lot of getting used to in my opinion. Watching the robot doing something that you’re not telling it to do seems confusing, but I’m sure it’s pretty powerful once the drivers become accustomed to it.

viggy96:

Automate as many tasks as possible. Each button shouldn’t just be controlling a motor (in general anyway). Each button should be a complete action, so as to ease the mental load on the driver. Further, if you find that you need two controllers for your robot, you likely haven’t automated enough functionality. This also plays into your design process; design a robot such that the common game actions are easy to automate.

This is 100% something I want to do. Our big limitation was how many motors with encoders or limit switches we had, so automation was interesting last year, but halfway through the competition we did automate our shooter and it made a noticeable difference in driver consistency.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
All of these are awesome suggestions. I’ll say traction control and tip detection aren’t as important for drive experience, but they are helpful especially in games with tippy robots.

One thing that hasn’t been mentioned much but is very useful: slow mode! When the left trigger is held down, scale your final joystick values by 0.3 or 0.4. This is immensely helpful for newer drivers when they’re trying to place something or align with precision, like in 2019 or 2023. Especially if you see your driver overcorrecting a lot during scoring, this can be very helpful.

Capping rotation speed can also be good, as you don’t usually need to turn insanely fast. Running PID on gyro heading can help prevent overturning as well.
